text: I'd like to talk a little bit, by way of introduction, about the native cultures of North America. And I'd like to present to you some concepts from anthropology. First is the concept of culture. There are many, many cultures on this planet, and anthropologists often talk about culture spheres, or areas that share a common culture. From a certain perspective, all of North America had a pretty similar culture, native culture, particularly I would say from the viewpoint of spirituality. However, it is possible to distinguish distinctive cultural areas in North America. So when you think about Indians, instead of only thinking of them in the generic sense, I'd like you to keep in mind what some of the major culture areas were. Probably the most typical image that the world has of an American Indian is an Indian from the Plains culture area. The Plains are basically from the Rockies to the Mississippi, and extend all the way into Canada. But the Plains were actually inhabited fairly late, really just a few hundred years ago, from the 17th century, basically 17th century on. And the culture that grew up there, which centered around the hunting of the buffalo, was an exceedingly rich culture, but as I say, a fairly recent culture. But that is the culture of the Sioux Indians, and also of a number of other groups like the Crow, and the Pawnee, the Kiowa, Comanche, and what have you. And that culture, particularly the Sioux culture, has become the world's image of the Indian, right? The one horseback with war bonnet, hunting the buffalo. That is the cigar store Indian, okay? That's the Indian head nickel Indian. And of course, that is also the Hollywood Indian. That of course was not the kinds of Indians that the Pilgrim Fathers encountered. That was quite a different culture area. The use of the horse was relatively late. It came in from Europe, but of course the Indians learned how to ride very well, and ride bareback at that, on the plains. Another distinctive culture area is the eastern woodlands and the lake area. Those are primarily Algonquian speakers. For example, the Chippewa, who are also known as the Ojibwe, would be an example of an Algonquian speaker. Names of rivers, names of mountains, names of states. When you trace them back, you'll find that they go back to Algonquian names. Algonquian is a language family. A group of languages that goes back to a common ancestor is called a language family. Now sometimes a language family can be a subfamily within a larger language family. If you think of how different Persian, English, and Russian are, yet they all go back to a common Indo-European language about 5,000 years ago. But think of the dispersion of that. That's a family. That was basically your status symbol. Status was wealth. Do you know what a potlatch is? Anybody here ever heard of a potlatch? It doesn't mean something you hold a pot down with. Potlatch is a display of your prowess where you give away enormous amounts of material goods, and then everybody that comes to the potlatch has to outdo you by giving away more. It's a contest in who can give away more, and that's how status was achieved in that culture. Of course, besides that kind of materialism, they had a spiritual dimension, and we'll be talking about that. There were other distinctive culture areas. The Southwest area is one. The interesting thing about the Navajo is they represent a little bit of a different line. It's believed that the indigenous peoples of North America came in three waves. Those were the Athabascan people, A-T-H-A-P-A-S-K-A-N, but it's pronounced Athabascan even though it's spelled with a P. Sometimes also called Nadene or Dine people. They arrived in their own wave. They weren't with the first wave of people to come from Europe. And then the last wave are represented by the Eskimos, and they're really quite late. But most of the Athabascans have disappeared or are in just very small bands. But one group of Athabascans, for whatever historical reasons I don't know, has grown to immense proportions, and that's the Navajo. When we compare two languages, here's what we compare. We compare the sound structure of the language. There are four areas in linguistics, phonology, which is sound system, morphology, which is word system, syntax, which is sentence system, and semantics, which is meaning system. So if you want to compare two languages, you compare phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics. Most languages, believe it or not, are pretty similar. They tend to fall into certain patterns. And the guy that was running it, he did it the Lakota way. He sang songs in the Sioux language. But he was a Papago. Papago, they call themselves now Tonaha'odom. The Pimas and the Papago are the same people. That's the basic tribe of the Tucson area. In fact, Tucson is a Papago name. Chukson means black well stream. Black spring, well stream, Chukson. Got corrupted to Tucson and then Tucson. He's a Papago. That's a Uto-Aztecan language family. That's another one of the families related to Aztec and Hopi. But he was doing Lakota ceremonies, and he did the sun dance the Lakota way. Fred, who you'll meet tomorrow, is a Kickapoo. But he'll do the sweat lodge the Lakota way, because he was trained by a Sioux. Every week I go to a sweat lodge down in San Pedro. It's a fantastic experience, because there are only a few non-Indians there. It's an all-Indian thing. But they welcome non-Indians. Sometimes they go around inside the sweat lodge, everybody says what tribe they are. I'm Pima, I'm Navajo, I'm Lakota. It's funny, when they get to me, I don't know quite what to say. The Lakota is called the white people Washiju. It's a very interesting name. Sometimes I say I'm Washiju, and then people laugh, because it's a little bit of a put-down name. It means the people that steal all the bacon. Washiju, literally, in the Lakota language. Washiju is bacon, and iju is to take. So the Washiju, the people that take the bacon. Sometimes I jokingly say that. But anyway, there's two lodges, a women's lodge and a men's lodge. Some tribes sweat co-ed, some tribes they keep the sexes separate. What you're going to discover is there's a lot of tribal differences. Traditional Lakota sweat lodges have both men and women, but they're separate. They have their own lodges, or they go in at different times. But anyway, it's all these urban Indians from all these different tribes from throughout North America, but all the songs and all the forms are the Lakota way. So if you learn Lakota songs and you learn Lakota forms, chances are you're going to feel comfortable throughout North America. What the Lakota did, therefore, is that they took these people that were culture-sided all throughout North America and they taught them what they knew. What they knew is how to use a pipe. What they knew is how to make a sweat lodge. What they knew is how to sun dance. What they knew is how to vision quest. These are the main expressions of contemporary American Indian spirituality. And then there's one other. There's the peyote religion. The peyote religion is not traditional for North America. The peyote religion is from Mexico. It's very traditional among the Aztecs and other Mexican Indian groups, like the Huichols and the Yaquis. If you've read any of the Don Juan material, it was a Yaqui. If you've read any of Barbara Meyerhoff's books, beautiful books about the Huichol Indians. The Huichols, the Yaquis, the Aztecs, the Mexican Indians had sacramental use of the peyote cactus. But that was not a North American Indian culture trait until about 100 years ago. What happened is after the Plains Indians were subjugated and forced onto reservations, they went through, of course, totally spiritual devastation. Because their ceremonies were prohibited, their sun dances were prohibited, and their whole way of life was destroyed and everything that made them have value in themselves was taken away. And they developed a religion called the ghost dance, which was a new religion, but they believed that if you danced long enough and danced hard enough, that the buffalo would come back, the white men would go away, and you'd be able to see your dead ancestors. They would dance until they would pass out. They would dance for days and days until they'd drop. This was the ghost dance. Some of you may know the tragic end to the ghost dance story. If you ever read Bury My Heart, it wounded me. What happened was, of course, there was a lot of fear of Indians among the white population, and any gathering of Indians might represent potential trouble. I believe it was 1891, just 100 years ago. There was a large gathering, and they were doing this ghost dance. Ghost dance is a big sacrifice, dancing for days and days and days without any rest like that. They would dance in a circle, all holding hands like little children. It was actually modeled after an Indian children's dance. And they said, you have to become like children again, and we have to sacrifice ourselves in this major way, and then the buffalo will come back, the white man will go away, we'll be able to see our dead ancestors. That's why it was called the ghost dance, because they wanted to see ghosts. They wanted to see their relatives, their relations that had passed away. And they were dancing like that, and if you've ever been to Indian spiritual things, you know, and I'll be describing to you tomorrow in detail what happens at these ceremonies. There's a very wonderful energy that's developed there. But unfortunately, the white community around didn't know enough about the cultures to know that it was a spiritual ceremony, and they were afraid. The upshot was, it ended that those people were all killed, including the children, the women, everyone. That was the massacre of wounded men. And that was the end of the ghost dance for a while. It's coming back now a little bit. But after that, there was total and utter devastation, because the ghost dance was sort of the last hope, you might say. And then what happened is, in the late 19th century, sacramental use of peyote was introduced up from Mexico and developed among the Plains Indians as a whole religion, as a new religion that mixed elements of Christianity. Often they'll have a Bible with the peyote button right on it. Mixed elements of Christianity, of white man's religion, elements from Mexican Indian religion, and then mixed with Plains Indian culture traits, developed into something that is officially called the Native American Church, but often referred to as the peyote way. But that's a really new religion, and a lot of traditional Indians won't follow it. They say, that's not a traditional Indian religion. But it is very Indian, and if you've ever had the privilege of being at a peyote ceremony, I don't know how many of you have ever done. I mean, an Indian, not just sitting around eating peyote, but I mean a Native American church ceremony. It is very Native, but it is a fairly new religion up here. It's sometimes called a teepee meeting. It's done in teepees. So you have the main culture traits, the main spiritual practices of North America, the use of a pipe as a focusing device, the sweat lodge, the vision quest, the sun dance. And then you have the peyote religion, which is really, as I say, a different critter. It's not unusual to find people that practice vision quest, sun dance, sweat lodge, and also practice the peyote religion. That's not an unusual combination, but you also get people that only practice the peyote religion and don't do these other things. And then you get many people that sun dance that would never think of eating peyote. They would consider it to be not an Indian religion. So these are the use of the pipe, what happens in the sweat lodge, what happens when you are, as they say, put on the hill. Put on the hill means you're put out to vision quest for four days. And what happens at a sun dance, and what happens at the peyote meetings. These are some of the spiritual practices that I'm going to be talking about in detail tomorrow. And as you know, we're going to have a sweat lodge ceremony available to you. I'd like to say a couple words about the sweat lodge. First of all, I know there's some people that are a little reticent to do it. So I'd like to encourage all of you to do it. The reticence might be that you fear it may be hot in there. I mean, uncomfortably hot. Obviously it's going to be a little bit hot. Sweat lodges were a ubiquitous North American Indian culture trait. Most tribes didn't. As I say, it now is often done the Sioux or Lakota way. However, in addition to the different tribal ways of doing sweats, the individual character of the sweat leader is very important. Oh, by the way, I just want to make a little aside. This isn't an EST seminar, so if you need to go to the bathroom, please feel free to get up. There are individual personal styles of doing the sweat in addition to the tribal traditions. It is true that some people run what's called warrior sweats. This tends to be quite a challenge. However, the people that are running the sweat tomorrow believe in a very different philosophy about the sweat lodge. They do not believe that it should be inordinately uncomfortable or purposefully made uncomfortable. After all, the sweat lodge is Indian equivalent to a church. Yes, you make some sacrifice. You have to sit there, and it may be several hours. You're on the ground. You're cramped. But they're not going to intentionally, as I once heard it phrased, they're not going to purify you. You know, we call it a sweat lodge, but they call it a purification lodge. Actually, in the Lakota language, it's called inipi. That's a really interesting word, inipi, I-N-I-P-I. P is the same P as in tipi. P is a pluralizing suffix. Tipi means they live in it. Ti means to dwell or to live. Tipi, P makes it plural. Tipi means they live in it. Inipi, the stem ni in Lakota, means two things, to live and to breathe. And i means for the purpose of. So inipi means they do it so that they can live and breathe. It's a purification ceremony. And we'll be talking a lot about what's meant in Buddhism and in native ways about what's meant by purification. So inipi is a purification, but they're not going to purify you. Not on purpose, anyway. Not intentionally. Well, sometimes the rocks have a mind of their own. You address the rocks as people when they come in the lodge. They're called stone people. And you do have to accept what the stone people teach you. But they don't run one of these warrior sweats where it's an endurance contest. And if you need to leave, it's OK to leave. When they do a warrior sweat, it's not OK to leave. I sweat with people that do warrior sweats sometimes, and it is definitely not OK to leave. And if you do leave, you're made to feel that it was not OK to leave. But that is not the way Fred and Wolf run their sweats. I guess the word I would use in contemporary idiom is going to be user-friendly. In every sense of the word. So user-friendly inipi. That would be a great logo, huh? Anyway, so they're going to make you feel real comfortable in there. As comfortable as possible. Some people have claustrophobia. OK, that's something to face in there and to work on. The sweat lodge is a womb. It's shaped like a womb. You feel like a womb. Everything in there is to support you. Everybody in there is to support each other. When you go into a sweat lodge, when you go in, in English you say, all my relations, you're calling upon. The whole relatedness of the universe is there for you. In the Sioux language, some of you know it, you'll hear it very often if you start going to Indian things. Aho, mitak oyasi. Mitak oyasi. It means all my relations. So you're in there with all your relations in this womb that's in the center of the universe. And it is the safest place in the world. If you have some claustrophobia or something like that, that's the place, if you have fear of darkness, that's the place to go where it's really safe and supportive, where you can work that fear through. I think you all know you wear swimsuits or cover yourself with towels so there's no nakedness or anything like that. There's no embarrassment about those kinds of things. And if you need to leave, you can leave. You can come back. It's not going to be a pressured thing. So I would encourage all of you to do it. We'll be doing it. You never tell until the last minute how a ceremony is going to come down. But here's what I think is going to happen. Typically a sweat lodge is four rounds. That means the door is open and new rocks are brought in four times. Then the door is closed and water is poured on the rocks and there's heat. And you do what's called four doors or four rounds. You open and close four times. Probably what's going to happen is that half of you will go in for the first two rounds. How long will that last? I don't know. Could be an hour, could be an hour and a half. I don't know. And the other half will sit around or stand around the sweat lodge and listen very carefully and participate in what's going on. So you won't be milling around. It's very typical when you go to a sweat lodge that the people who aren't in the sweat lodge are right next to the sweat lodge. They're hunched down, they're sitting, they're with the people in the sweat lodge. So half of you will be in, the other half will be with the ones that are in around the periphery and then you'll alternate. The door is going to open and close. You can come and you can return as you need. So you don't have to feel there's any pressure in there. Everything that you need to know as far as the decorum of the ceremony is going to be explained to you. If you make a mistake, that's okay. That's part of the ceremony. Making mistakes is part of the ceremony. Don't worry about it. But I can tell you how to avoid making mistakes. Just don't do anything unless you ask the sweat leader's permission. It's as simple as that. You don't talk unless you ask his permission and he'll give it. You don't sing unless you ask his permission and he'll give it. It's as simple as that. The attitude is at ease, but not chatty. It is a sacred ceremony. So he may joke around, but don't think that that means that now it's okay, now we're going to be real hippy-dippy and start oming and do whatever we want. No, it's not going to be that way. He runs a traditional Lakota sweat lodge and will be singing songs. The songs will be in the Lakota language mostly, although they might do a Chumash song or he'll probably maybe do a Kickapoo song from his own people. If you can follow with the song, fine, but if you can't, don't mess up the song. You learn by imitating, but sometimes I notice Americans, they get real creative in there. You don't want to get creative in there. Sing in a small voice if you're trying to follow along so that the people that know the songs can wail. So what I say is it's informal, but on the other hand, you'll be observing certain... You'll know the feeling tone. And definitely, it's just like an AA meeting, no cross-talk. That's absolutely for sure, no cross-talk inside there. So I'd like to, as I say, encourage everyone to come. And if you have any feelings, like you have some reticence, maybe some issue that I haven't brought up here, please come to me and we'll talk about it. I won't pressure you to do it, but let's talk about it. However, when we go into their culture, my feeling is that we can't judge. We have to accept their culture. And there is an aspect of their culture that some non-Indians have a little difficulty relating to, although I think it does make sense. But I will ask you to absolutely and totally honor this aspect of the Lakota culture. And that is that with respect to any ceremony, sweat lodge, use of the pipe, even the hearing of song and sun dancing, when a woman is on her moon period, it's considered the most powerful of all ceremonies. And moon period, it means the menstrual cycle. They call it the moon. When you're on your moon, it's the most powerful of all ceremonies because it's the most powerful purification. And they do not mix that with any other ceremony. So I'd ask you to observe that. And sometimes it's real hard. But what you're going to discover is what's involved with these ceremonies is always sacrifice. And sometimes that sacrifice, it's a real sacrifice. Sometimes the sacrifice is physical. Maybe you're in a warrior sweat and you have to sit through heat. Or you're in a peyote meeting and you sit 18 hours on one spot. Don't even go up to pee, okay? Because you don't want to break the circle of that peyote meeting. And all night, no sleep. Maybe it's a vision quest. Four days, four nights, alone. No food, no water, no shelter, no sleep. It's a sacrifice. Maybe it's the sacrifice of not knowing if the ceremony is going to happen. You travel three states. And maybe the ceremony will happen and maybe it won't. And you don't know. Or maybe it will happen but there's not room for you. I'm talking about my own experience here, okay? It's a sacrifice. Where you don't know when the ceremony is going to happen. It's going to happen sometime in the end of August. Like the Sundance that I go to. It happens sometime in the end of August. It means I have to have, in order to go to that four-day ceremony, I have to leave a month clear, two weeks on either side, of no commitment whatsoever or I'll not be able to go to that ceremony. That's a sacrifice. It's inconvenient. These ceremonies are inconvenient. And that's part of the learning. One of the inconveniences is when a woman's on her moon, she doesn't go to these other ceremonies. In the traditional culture, she goes to the moon lodge. If you go to a Sundance, they have moon lodges there. It's a tipi for women. And older women come and tell them stories and talk to them. And it's a whole alone, sacred time for them. But I would, because it's not our culture, sometimes people don't respect this aspect of their culture. They say, well, I'll go anyway, kind of thing. And that's not a good way. So I would ask you to understand about that. Tomorrow I'll be talking in a little more detail about what happens, not just at the sweat lodge, but in these other ceremonies. And I'll be talking about how it is that these ceremonies bring about similar evolution of consciousness to Buddhist meditation. And we'll be starting, it's 10, isn't it, in the morning? We'll be going from 10 until around noontime. You'll have a light lunch, really light lunch. I actually recommend fasting. And then in the afternoon, we'll be going into the sweat itself. And tomorrow's meeting, I think you all know, is on Mary's property, where the sweat lodge is. So in the morning, we'll be a class like this. Then I get to take off my white man professor's hat, and I just become a student again. Because it's my teacher that's running the sweat. And I have nothing more to say at that point. And he'll be taking over. Any questions? Indians are still suffering, big time. Not maybe in quite the cultural genocide ways of the past, but the legacy of that suffering is still with them. That's why the spiritual renaissance was necessary. The modern Red Road, by the way, when they say Red Road, it doesn't mean the Red Man's Path. Canku Luta, in the Lakota language. Luta is red as a sacred, because there's two words for red in Lakota. One means red just as the color red. The other means red as a sacred color. They both mean red, though. You know Machkia Luta, red cloud? That's the luta, wa luta. That luta, we are called luta, I know an Indian named Red Feather. They use a special word for red when they talk about religion. Red is the sacred color. So when they talk about the Red Road, that means the spiritual path. It doesn't mean the Red Man's religion as opposed to the White Man's religion. You'll see that there are four color flags. Red, white, black, and yellow. They stand for the four directions, but they also stand for the four races. All races are welcome in traditional Indian culture. But anyway, the answer to your question is, the material and psychological situation of the contemporary American Indian is devastating. Devastating. And the only thing that helps that I've ever seen is these ceremonies. Because, and we'll be discussing tomorrow, how ceremony empowers and purifies a person. So the contemporary Red Road is actually perhaps even spiritually deeper than it was in the past. Because it's the medicine that they need for alcoholism, for all the things that they've had imposed upon them, for the psychological devastation that they went through. And that's why these people do this practice. I mentioned that I sweat with a group every Wednesday. It's called Eagle Lodge. It's a recovery program for Native Americans. They take people that are just getting sober, just out of prison, a lifetime of using drugs and drinking alcohol, a lifetime in and out of jail, is the typical life story of the people that I sweat with. I would say 95% of them. And they take people just out of jail, just off of Skid Row. They put them in those warrior sweats. And they get them to cry, and to endure incredible discomforts, and to talk from a place that's beyond the intellect. And afterwards they feel clean. And they come back, despite the suffering. And they come back, it's like funny to hear somebody say, you know, I haven't been to the lodge in four months, but I just had to come back, I miss the suffering. You wonder what they're talking about. They're cleaning themselves out. And basically, yes, it still goes on. It's terrible what they have to live with. And these ceremonies are what make the suffering bearable. And then ultimately what make it a purification. So you might say their life is hard, and their religion is even harder. But hard in a special way. Attitudes among Native Americans about white people getting involved in their religion run the whole gamut. Remember, us going into their sacred ceremonies is roughly equivalent to ex-Nazis at High Holy Day services. The fact that you may well be welcomed is an indication of something right there. You'll run the whole gamut. On one hand, and I've had the whole experience, I've had it in there where I got ragged on for being a white man in a sweat lodge, and you're burning up in there, and you're at your wits end, and you're just barely holding on, and you're about to cry, and suddenly somebody starts ragging on you for being a white man. It's quite an amazing experience. You run the whole gamut from, you know, like, you don't belong here, what are you doing here, that kind of stuff. The whole gamut from that to the other end of the spectrum, people like Fred and Tom and Wallace Black Elk and a lot of very prominent Indian leaders that say, our Red Road won't work unless we include the four colors. You always have the four-color flags. How do you expect the ceremonies to work unless the four colors of the races that they symbolize are there at the ceremony? And for people like Fred, it is absolutely part and parcel of the Red Road that white people have to be there, and black people and Asians, or the ceremonies won't work. So you run the whole gamut. It's quite an interesting thing. And you never quite know what you're going to run into. First time I ever went to a sundown as a supporter was one of these all-Indian deals. And they had their own internal police, AIM types, you know, real militant, full-blood. You know, man, you walk in there, you just don't know what you're going to get into. But it so happened we were welcomed, welcomed with open arms. So anyway, we're actually, we've run out of our time, unfortunately. We have to vacate at 10, I believe. I think I've answered all your questions. And tomorrow, you know what we'll be talking about and what we'll be doing. So if you have any other issues as we're cleaning up here, come up to me or you can come up to Gina. And I'll be looking forward to seeing you all tomorrow.

segments.text: I'd like to talk a little bit, by way of introduction, about the native cultures of North America.
And I'd like to present to you some concepts from anthropology.
First is the concept of culture.
There are many, many cultures on this planet, and anthropologists often talk about culture
spheres, or areas that share a common culture.
From a certain perspective, all of North America had a pretty similar culture, native culture,
particularly I would say from the viewpoint of spirituality.
However, it is possible to distinguish distinctive cultural areas in North America.
So when you think about Indians, instead of only thinking of them in the generic sense,
I'd like you to keep in mind what some of the major culture areas were.
Probably the most typical image that the world has of an American Indian is an Indian from
the Plains culture area.
The Plains are basically from the Rockies to the Mississippi, and extend all the way
into Canada.
But the Plains were actually inhabited fairly late, really just a few hundred years ago,
from the 17th century, basically 17th century on.
And the culture that grew up there, which centered around the hunting of the buffalo,
was an exceedingly rich culture, but as I say, a fairly recent culture.
But that is the culture of the Sioux Indians, and also of a number of other groups like
the Crow, and the Pawnee, the Kiowa, Comanche, and what have you.
And that culture, particularly the Sioux culture, has become the world's image of the Indian,
right?
The one horseback with war bonnet, hunting the buffalo.
That is the cigar store Indian, okay?
That's the Indian head nickel Indian.
And of course, that is also the Hollywood Indian.
Often you'll find in art, for example, when the Pilgrim Fathers are being portrayed, interacting
with Indians, what they show is like an Indian with war bonnets, and breastplates, and all
of these sorts of things.
That of course was not the kinds of Indians that the Pilgrim Fathers encountered.
That was quite a different culture area.
The use of the horse was relatively late.
It came in from Europe, but of course the Indians learned how to ride very well, and
ride bareback at that, on the plains.
Another distinctive culture area is the eastern woodlands and the lake area.
Those are primarily Algonquian speakers.
For example, the Chippewa, who are also known as the Ojibwe, would be an example of an Algonquian
speaker.
And there was one other linguistic group there, the Iroquoian languages in New York State.
But most of New England and most of the Great Lakes areas, the eastern woodlands of the
United States, had an Algonquian language base there, and therefore an enormous number
of American place names.
Names of rivers, names of mountains, names of states.
When you trace them back, you'll find that they go back to Algonquian names.
Algonquian is a language family.
Just as, well, you know that the, what do Spanish, French, Italian, Portuguese, and
Romanian have in common?
They all trace back to a common ancestor.
They're called romance languages, meaning not that they're essentially romantic, but
that they come from Rome.
In other words, they go back to the Latin language.
A group of languages that goes back to a common ancestor is called a language family.
Now sometimes a language family can be a subfamily within a larger language family.
For example, the romance languages represent a subfamily within a much bigger family.
And what is that bigger family called?
Well Sanskrit is a particular language.
Indo-European.
A well-named name because it spans most of the languages between India and Europe.
Indo-European has ten branches.
The Celtic languages are Indo-European.
The Slavic languages, Polish, Russian, are Indo-European.
Persian and Sanskrit, and therefore all the languages of North India, are Indo-European.
The Germanic languages are Indo-European.
Greek is Indo-European.
Latin and all of the languages derived from Latin are Indo-European.
As well as Albanian, Armenian, and Hittite, the Hittites mentioned in the Old Testament.
And a group that you've never heard of I'm sure called the Tokarians who lived all the
way in China, but they spoke Indo-European.
So that's a humongous language family.
You can see what a large language family, how widespread it can be.
In the New World, there are dozens of language families as big as Indo-European, that is
to say as diverse.
If you think of how different Persian, English, and Russian are, yet they all go back to a
common Indo-European language about 5,000 years ago.
But think of the dispersion of that.
That's a family.
Now there are several dozen language families in North America.
And then each of those language families could have one to dozens of individual languages
inside.
Now one of the major language families is Algonquian.
Tomorrow you'll be meeting my mentor on the Red Road, Fred Wapapa.
Wapapa is a very typical Kickapoo name.
The Sac and Fox and Kickapoo are the same tribe basically.
They originally came from the Great Lakes area, but they were resettled in Oklahoma.
Some of them went all the way down into Mexico and still live in Mexico.
They're an Algonquian people, like the Ojibwe.
So that means that their language is ultimately related to the languages like the Mohicans
and those types of people of the eastern seaboard.
But the Sioux language is its own language family.
And it's related to Winnebago, which is spoken in Wisconsin.
In fact, the Sioux people came originally from the Minnesota area, the Minnesota-Wisconsin
area, and they moved westward onto the plains.
So that's a whole language family called Siouan languages.
Quite different.
So you have language families in North America, and you also have culture areas in North America.
I mentioned two culture areas, the eastern woodlands culture, which is primarily dominated
by Algonquian speakers, and has left a very, as I mentioned, a very strong imprint on the
place names in America.
Then there is the plains culture area.
California was a distinctive culture sphere of its own, and had a lot of interesting distinctive
features.
The Indians that lived here, do you know what the staple food was here?
That's correct, yeah.
It's very abundant.
There's a lot of oak around.
And have any of you ever eaten?
I've eaten what they ate.
It's quite interesting.
You take the acorns, they discovered that if you mash it up, and I think you mix it
with lime, you can leach out a lot of the yucky stuff that's in there that will make
you sick.
And you mash it up, and what they would do is they would take baskets, put the mash in
there, and then they would heat rocks.
Tomorrow you'll find out how rocks can be heated, used to heat human beings too.
But they would heat rocks and put it in these baskets.
You may wonder how people cooked and boiled in a culture where they only knew how to weave
baskets, they didn't have metal or whatever.
They put the rocks inside the food, and they'd stir the rocks around with long sticks, like
giant, like huge, like chopsticks for the Jolly Green Giant, actually is what it looked
like.
They would move these rocks around in there, and that's how they'd cook it, and they'd
make this stuff that's sort of like poi, that the Hawaiians eat.
And anyway, that was the staple food here, all throughout California.
There was a distinctive culture here.
One of the things that distinguished California was it was exceedingly linguistically diverse.
In other words, it's not just in recent times that California has this melting pot kind
of thing, where it tends to attract people from all over.
Most of the language families of North America have representatives in California.
In other words, people tended to migrate here in pre-Columbian times, just like they do
now.
You know, like you say, there's no one who's born here, people tend to come.
That's an old, old pattern that's been going on from the Indian times, and it's reflected
in the linguistic diversity of California in native times.
The major California language families, you've never heard of them, I'm sure, but they're
called Hokan and Panutian.
If you look at the language map of California, it's very, very interesting.
The central part of California is dominated by the Panutian languages, of which there
were dozens.
And then all around the rim of California are primarily Hokan languages, and then inclusions
of languages from other parts of North America.
So apparently what happened was the Panutian core came up into the center of California
and sort of spread out.
Hokan is probably the original language family of California.
One of the Hokan languages is Chumash.
Now we're smack dab in the middle of Chumash territory right here.
Actually they call themselves Chumash, but the Spanish corrupted it to Chumash.
Malibu, okay, Mohalibu, I think it means in Chumash the place where the surf pounds loud.
I'm pretty sure that Point Magoo, I think Magoo means tar or something like that.
Do they have tar now?
I don't know.
But Ojai is from Ahwai in Chumash, that means the moon.
What are some of the other places around here?
Saticoy, I forgot what that means, that's Chumash.
All over, we're right in the heart of the Chumash territory.
But Chumash is one representative of the Hokan languages and there were dozens spoken in
